article.headline: SE Louisiana 128, Dallas Christian 42
article.story: HAMMOND, La. (AP) -- Kevyn Green scored 28 points as he led six players in double figures and Southeastern Louisiana shattered a pair of records in a 128-42 rout of Dallas Christian on Friday. Jeremy Dunbar added 22 points and Tavaris Nance 21 as Southeastern (2-1) established single-game records for the largest margin of victory and most field goals made (53). The Lions' previous margin of victory came in 1993-94 in a 100-37 win over Baptist Christian while Southeastern's 53 field goals broke the previous record (48) set against Texas College in 1997-98. David Ndoumba added 13 points and a game-high 16 rebounds for Southeastern, which tied a school-record with 17 3-pointers, while Patrick Sullivan added 12 points, 13 rebounds and Daryl Arnold chipped in 10 to set season-highs. Southeastern spotted Dallas Christian (0-7) a 2-0 lead on a tip-in by Brandon Dewalt, but the Lions never trailed again after Green drained the first of his six 3-pointers in the game on the next possession. Nance capped a 14-2 run for the Lions with a 3-pointer and Southeastern upped its lead to 29-9 on a 3-pointer by Green with 9:00 remaining. The Lions led by as many as 39 points in the first half and took a 60-24 lead into halftime before outscoring the Crusaders, 68-18, in the second half. Southeastern, which had all 10 players who dressed for the game enter the scoring column, got 52 points from its bench and scored 41 points off 21 Dallas Christian turnovers. Stephen Mawire led Dallas Christian, which was limited to six players and shot 26 percent (15-for-57) for the game, with 11 points. Dalon Parker and Jon Ramer added nine points each for the Crusaders.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).
